NEW YORK CONSULTING ENGINEER TELLS STUDENTS
OF POWER DEVELOPMENT
Mr. Geo. A. Orrick Addresses
Engineering Upperclassmen
'•1 he tremendous developments
and inventions of new machinery
in the last century have enabled
one man to accomplish in industry what formerly required six
hundred and thirty-five men to
do," was the declaration of George
A. Orrick, noted consulting engineer, of New York City.
Mr. Orrick, who addressed a
group of engineering upper-classmen last Monday, April 30, on the
subject of "Power Development,
Past and Future," is the director
and builder of many of the lagest
power plants in the East during
the last quarter of a century. The
engineer illustrated his talk by
means of profuse slides, tables
and diagrams. Photographs of
the largest power stations, both
steam and electric, in the United
States were shown.
The growth of industry in the
United States was traced, from
the development of the steam engine and boiler by James Watt to
the present era, in which one-half
of all power in the world is used
by this country. Watt was declared by Mr. Orrick to be more
responsible than any other man
for this growth, because of his invention of the steam condensor,
water jacket, engine governor and
steam indicator.
Nearly a century elapsed after
Watt's invention before full development of the steam engine occurred. This was largely due to
the invention of the incandescent
lamp by Edison, and the subsequent growth of electricity in industry. The greatest development
occurred during the early part of
1900, when De Lav-al and Parsons
produced their turbines. These
reduced labor, oil, and repair to
a marked degree.
Engines are now using 60 per
cent, of the fuel that would have
been necessary in 1900 to deliver
the same power. Achievements
have brought the efficiency of
steam boilers to almost the theoretical limit. The remarkable advancement was graphically shown
when Mr. Orrick stated, "In past
years 400 billion ton-miles of
freight were transported. To do
this a century ago would have necessitated the use of a billion and
a quarter men."
The steam engine took thirty
years to develop and twenty years
to perfect to its present high degree. Few engineers look to see
any marked increase in its efficiency. However, Mr. Orrick declared that the end is not in sight
for turbine development.
This lecture was the last of a
series on "Engineering Practice,"
given annually under the auspices
of the Johns Hopkins School of
Engineering.

BALTIMORE, MD., MAY 8, 1923

THE PRESIDENT OF THE STUDENT COUNCIL
For over a month members of the Senior Class have been folding
up their tents and quietly withdrawing from the leadership of undergraduate activities. They have, one by one, relinquished the responsibility which they have borne for four years and have turned to the
sterner task of graduation and the taking up of their life's work. The
Juniors, timid and uncertain of their ability, have stepped in, and,
guided by the more experienced hands of the Seniors, have gradually
assumed control of undergraduate affairs.
The student body, however, still has its most important task
before it. It must select, next Thursday, the man who is to be its
acknowledged leader for the coming collegiate year. And hut few
realize the importance of this election. The President of the Student
Council is the most influential and, at the same time, one of the most
powerful men on the campus. As the acknowledged head he dictates, for a large part, the policies and is the representative from the
student body to the outside world. It is to him that the Faculty,
the press and other colleges turn when they desire the views of the
Hopkins undergraduates.
It is with these thoughts in mind that we shudder as we note
the general indifference and nonchalance concerning the coming elections. The man chosen for this position must possess certain definite qualities. He must be respected and admired by the students
and must be one worthy to represent and to speak for Hopkins off
of the campus. It is essential that, during the next two days, the
name of each candidate be carefully considered and his qualities thoroughly analyzed. We could not atttempt to indicate the harm which
the wrong man in such a position might bring about.
FAILURE?
At the beginning of the collegiate year a committee was appointed to consider the advisability of a June Week. This committee, upon investigation, decided that Johns Hopkins had grown to
such an extent that it could stage festivities on an elaborate scale.
It felt that the undergraduates would not support mediocrity and no
expense was spared in the making of preparations.
At present, with four weeks to go, all is in readiness. Nationally
known orchestra have been procured, halls have been rented, decorations are in the process of completion. The stage is set for a week of
festivities such as Johns Hopkins has never experienced. Contracts,
signed by the committee, aggregate several thousands of dollars.
With this comes the announcement that the undergraduate body
has failed. At a meeting of the committee held last week it was
announced that but twenty-eight tickets had been paid for.
It is essential that three hundred tickets be sold. The committee,
while asserting that "the affair will be put over right or not at all,"
maintains confidence in the student body. Less than two weeks re-main before final returns must be in. A successful June Week would
be an unbeatable advertisement for the "new" Johns Hopkins. Failure
would not only be difficult to live down, but would also be a distinct disappointment to many who are looking forward to the events.
The matter remains in the hands of the undergraduates. Neither
committee nor students will consent to mediocrity. Will our first
June Week, advertised throughout the State for six months, be called
off? The ticket .sale, during the next two weeks, will answer the
query.

NEW YORK CONSULTING ENGINEER TELLS STUDENTS
OF POWER DEVELOPMENT
Mr. Geo. A. Orrick Addresses
Engineering Upperclassmen
'•1 he tremendous developments
and inventions of new machinery
in the last century have enabled
one man to accomplish in industry what formerly required six
hundred and thirty-five men to
do," was the declaration of George
A. Orrick, noted consulting engineer, of New York City.
Mr. Orrick, who addressed a
group of engineering upper-classmen last Monday, April 30, on the
subject of "Power Development,
Past and Future," is the director
and builder of many of the lagest
power plants in the East during
the last quarter of a century. The
engineer illustrated his talk by
means of profuse slides, tables
and diagrams. Photographs of
the largest power stations, both
steam and electric, in the United
States were shown.
The growth of industry in the
United States was traced, from
the development of the steam engine and boiler by James Watt to
the present era, in which one-half
of all power in the world is used
by this country. Watt was declared by Mr. Orrick to be more
responsible than any other man
for this growth, because of his invention of the steam condensor,
water jacket, engine governor and
steam indicator.
Nearly a century elapsed after
Watt's invention before full development of the steam engine occurred. This was largely due to
the invention of the incandescent
lamp by Edison, and the subsequent growth of electricity in industry. The greatest development
occurred during the early part of
1900, when De Lav-al and Parsons
produced their turbines. These
reduced labor, oil, and repair to
a marked degree.
Engines are now using 60 per
cent, of the fuel that would have
been necessary in 1900 to deliver
the same power. Achievements
have brought the efficiency of
steam boilers to almost the theoretical limit. The remarkable advancement was graphically shown
when Mr. Orrick stated, "In past
years 400 billion ton-miles of
freight were transported. To do
this a century ago would have necessitated the use of a billion and
a quarter men."
The steam engine took thirty
years to develop and twenty years
to perfect to its present high degree. Few engineers look to see
any marked increase in its efficiency. However, Mr. Orrick declared that the end is not in sight
for turbine development.
This lecture was the last of a
series on "Engineering Practice,"
given annually under the auspices
of the Johns Hopkins School of
Engineering.

BALTIMORE, MD., MAY 8, 1923

THE PRESIDENT OF THE STUDENT COUNCIL
For over a month members of the Senior Class have been folding
up their tents and quietly withdrawing from the leadership of undergraduate activities. They have, one by one, relinquished the responsibility which they have borne for four years and have turned to the
sterner task of graduation and the taking up of their life's work. The
Juniors, timid and uncertain of their ability, have stepped in, and,
guided by the more experienced hands of the Seniors, have gradually
assumed control of undergraduate affairs.
The student body, however, still has its most important task
before it. It must select, next Thursday, the man who is to be its
acknowledged leader for the coming collegiate year. And hut few
realize the importance of this election. The President of the Student
Council is the most influential and, at the same time, one of the most
powerful men on the campus. As the acknowledged head he dictates, for a large part, the policies and is the representative from the
student body to the outside world. It is to him that the Faculty,
the press and other colleges turn when they desire the views of the
Hopkins undergraduates.
It is with these thoughts in mind that we shudder as we note
the general indifference and nonchalance concerning the coming elections. The man chosen for this position must possess certain definite qualities. He must be respected and admired by the students
and must be one worthy to represent and to speak for Hopkins off
of the campus. It is essential that, during the next two days, the
name of each candidate be carefully considered and his qualities thoroughly analyzed. We could not atttempt to indicate the harm which
the wrong man in such a position might bring about.
FAILURE?
At the beginning of the collegiate year a committee was appointed to consider the advisability of a June Week. This committee, upon investigation, decided that Johns Hopkins had grown to
such an extent that it could stage festivities on an elaborate scale.
It felt that the undergraduates would not support mediocrity and no
expense was spared in the making of preparations.
At present, with four weeks to go, all is in readiness. Nationally
known orchestra have been procured, halls have been rented, decorations are in the process of completion. The stage is set for a week of
festivities such as Johns Hopkins has never experienced. Contracts,
signed by the committee, aggregate several thousands of dollars.
With this comes the announcement that the undergraduate body
has failed. At a meeting of the committee held last week it was
announced that but twenty-eight tickets had been paid for.
It is essential that three hundred tickets be sold. The committee,
while asserting that "the affair will be put over right or not at all,"
maintains confidence in the student body. Less than two weeks re-main before final returns must be in. A successful June Week would
be an unbeatable advertisement for the "new" Johns Hopkins. Failure
would not only be difficult to live down, but would also be a distinct disappointment to many who are looking forward to the events.
The matter remains in the hands of the undergraduates. Neither
committee nor students will consent to mediocrity. Will our first
June Week, advertised throughout the State for six months, be called
off? The ticket .sale, during the next two weeks, will answer the
query.
